content.info: Nutrition is the study of nutrients in food, how the body uses nutrients, and the relationship between diet, health, and disease.
A nutrient is a source of nourishment, a component of food, for instance, protein, carbohydrate, fat, vitamin, mineral, fiber, and water.
Macronutrients are nutrients we need in relatively large quantities.
Micronutrients are nutrients we need in relatively small quantities.
Macronutrients can be further split into energy macronutrients (that provide energy), and macronutrients that do not provide energy.

subtopics.title: Carbohydrates
parts: Are a macronutriet
4 kcal per gram
Carbohydrate molecules include monosaccharides (glucose, fructose, galactose), disaccharides, and polysaccharides (starch)

subtopics.title: Fats
parts: Are a macronutriet
Fats - 9 kcal per gram

Fats are required in the diet for health as they serve many functions, including lubricating joints, helping organs produce hormones, assisting in absorption of certain vitamins, reducing inflammation, and preserving brain health.
There are different types of fats such as saturated fats, Unstaturaed fats like monounsaturated fats and polyunsaturated fats, lasty Trans fats
Unsaturated fats are liquid at room temperature
Saturated fats are solid at room temperature
Trans fats  are made by heating liquid vegetable oils in the presence of hydrogen gas and a catalyst, a process called hydrogenation.

subtopics.title: Proteins
parts: Are a macronutriet
Proteins - 4 kcal per gram
Proteins are used to produce new tissues for growth and tissue repair and regulate and maintain body functions.

subtopics.title: Vitamins
parts: Are a micronutrients
These are organic compounds we require in tiny amounts. (An organic compound is any molecule that contains carbon.)
It is called a vitamin when our bodies cannot synthesize (produce) enough or any of it, so we need to get it from our food.

subtopics.title: Minerals
parts: Dietary minerals are the other chemical elements our bodies need, other than carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen.

With that in mind, it is encouraged to keep up to date on what is recommened for your body at least in a 5 year span of study

subtopics.title: Diet planning
parts: A diet plan can easily be put together, in many different ways but there are a 5 things to keep in mind
Follow a healthy eating pattern across the lifespan. All food and beverage choices matter.
Focus on variety, nutrient density, and amount.
Limit calories from added sugars and saturated fats and reduce sodium intake.
Shift to healthier food and beverage choices.
Support healthy eating patterns for all.

subtopics.title: Metabolism
parts: Metabolism is the process by which your body converts what you eat and drink into energy.
Even when you're at rest, your body needs energy for all its "hidden" functions, such as breathing, circulating blood, adjusting hormone levels, and growing and repairing cells.
Several factors determine your individual baseline metabolism, including such as your body size, your biological sex and your age
Just keep in mind that, metabolism is a natural process, your body has many mechanisms that regulate it to meet your individual needs.

subtopics.title: Determining how much you need to consume
parts: In order to determine what you need to consume you need to know, what your body consumes daily
The first reference below, appendix-2 tells you a "Estimated Calorie Needs per Day, by Age, Sex, and Physical Activity Level"
The second reference below, appendix-7 tells you "Nutritional Goals for Age-Sex Groups Based on Dietary Reference Intakes and Dietary Guidelines Recommendations"
The third reference below, is a online calculator that you can use to determine your current total daily energy expenditure.

To gain weight you need to consume more calories than your body needs. To lose weight, you need to consume less than what your body needs. Lastly if you want to stay the same, just consume roughly what you need
Take the time to follow these sources to get a general idea on how much you need to consume!

subtopics.title: Reading food labels and understanding what they mean
parts: The nutrition facts should be pretty straight foward to read, just keep in mind the calories are per serving size and the percentage on the right hand side are based on a 2000 calorie diets
The FDA sets specific rules for what food certain labels mean on packaging
"Healthy" food must be low in fat, with limited cholesterol and sodium.
Anything labeled "free" must only contain tiny amounts of the ingredient in each serving.
A serving of a food labeled "low sodium" can have a maximum of 140 milligrams of sodium.
One serving of a "low-fat" food can have a maximum of 3 grams of fat
One serving of a "light" food must have 50% less fat or 1/3 fewer calories than the regular version.
Organic products just means must be produced without conventional pesticides, synthetic fertilizers, biotechnology, or ionizing radiation.
Organic animals must be fed organic feed and not be injected with hormones or antibiotics.
